root: ^MCDOWELL: The other day I went to the shops and the bananas were two dollars a kilo! Imagine that!

g-0: ^MCDOWELL: ...Oh I know you love your bananas, but I don't think we can afford that with the way the shop is going.

s: ^I'm trying to buy this screwdriver part and... this power core too.

g-1: ^MCDOWELL: ...I don't know why you'd say that.

choi_IntroFirst: ^CHOI: ...well, these numbers don't even make sense... did she fuck them up somehow?
^ERGOMANIA: Ah, this is the guy that actually does the work around here. He'll appreciate being talked to first.

s: ^Hm... I'll leave you to your work for now. (Leave)

jennings_IntroFirst: ^ERGOMANIA: This is the guy that actually does the work around here. Should have talked to him first.
^CHOI: ...bastard... treating me like I'm his lackey when I'm...

choi_situationBrief: ^CHOI: So, you're here for the MetPhone situation?
^CHOI: You were quick. Usually takes them a week to send a guy down here.

g-1: ^PARANOIA: Why did he hesitate before saying "broke down"?
g-2: ^CHOI: I don't know, isn't it your job to figure that out?
^CHOI: It's giving us enough trouble as it is! Our power went out at the same time as the phone died, and we can't just leave this monitoring station. It's important stuff.
^CHOI: Good thing we found this generator to keep our gear running... still lost about six hours of work, but it's better than a complete shut down.
g-3: ^CHOI: The MetPhone's in the lowest basement level. Obviously. How do you not know that?
g-4: ^CHOI: Just take the stairs down. They're on the left of here.
^CHOI: Oh, by the way, what's your name?
g-5: ^CHOI: *Doctor* Jennings. He's the one in charge of the team.
^CHOI: Let me know if there's anything you need help with, I guess.

choi_InProgress: ^CHOI: ...if this is like this then how is it like that...

s: ^I've looked at the phone, looks like someone tampered with it.
^By the way, I found a very old phone in the basement. Know anything about it?

b: ^ So, where's the third member of your team?

choi_metphoneInspected: ^CHOI: Well, I haven't been down in the basement in months so it wouldn't be me, in case you're wondering.

s: ^The access panel to the core's got a bunch of scratches on it. My guess is someone removed the core from it.

g-1: ^CHOI: What do you mean your "guess", are you sure that's the cause?

s: ^It's the only part of it that is visibly damaged...
^Are you a mechanic? It's pretty obvious the core compartment's the cause.

g-2: ^CHOI: Right, okay. How long will it take for you to replace it?

s: ^I'd need to open it up first. Would there be any proprietary screwdriver bits lying around here?

g-3: ^CHOI: Doubt it. They removed anything useful before we moved in. Including auxiliary power.
^CHOI: There *is* a Hardware Store nearby that stocks... seemingly everything. That's where I got the generator.
^CHOI: They may have some Metcom-compatible stuff there too.
^CHOI: Uh... Anyway. Maybe you should check that out instead of looking around here.
^PARANOIA: He's hiding something... We sense guilt, but it's not about the phone.

b: ^ Maybe he's responsible for Petrakis running away...
^ Could it have something to do with that messy desk?
^ He *really* didn't want us to look around here. There must be something closeby he doesn't want us to see.

choi_oldphoneInspected: ^CHOI: An old phone? How old are we talking about?

s: ^VERY old. Made of wood and stuff.

g-0: ^CHOI: Hm. I... wouldn't know anything about something that old.
^CHOI: Jennings might, though. He's... obsessed with the past.

choi_petradeskDeflect: ^CHOI: That's not anyone's desk. It was like that even before we got there.

s: ^Multiple documents on it explicitly refer to "Dr. Jennings' research team"...

g-0: ^CHOI: Oh, well, of course. Um, Jennings must have put them on there.
^CHOI: How careless, to put our documents on some random desk... haha.
^PARANOIA: Oh he's lying. He's obviously lying to us.
^ERGOMANIA: Yeah, he's godawful at it. Poor bastard. Wonder what Jennings would have to say about the desk?

choi_petradeskConfess: ^CHOI: How... uh... um... there's no third member of the team. No idea what you're talking about.

s: ^Multiple documents on the desk explicitly refer to "Dr. Jennings' research team"...

c-0: ^CHOI: Oh, well, of course. Um, Jennings must have put them on there.
^CHOI: How careless, to put our documents on some random desk... haha.
^PARANOIA: Oh he's lying. He's obviously lying to us.

s: ^Look, Jennings told me about her. Petrakis, right?

g-1: ^CHOI: Fuck. Alright. Yeah, she was the other assistant.
^CHOI: She's always been an excentric, but recently she... well, she lost her mind.
^CHOI: Started talking about how the wires are listening in, something about "tendrils" and voices in DTMF signals... evil coming in from the MetPhone in the basement... crazy stuff.
^CHOI: Three days ago, she said she "took care of the source" and that she's "going to work off-site". Then the lights went out.
^CHOI: This is going to sound weird, but...
^CHOI: Can you check in on her? Although I only know she's staying at a hotel, but I don't know which.

s: ^Yeah. Acheron Hotel. It's not too far from here.
^I can see if she left any clues on her desk.
^Wait, why did you lie and pretend she didn't exist?
^(Letting the whole lying thing slide) Cool.

c-5: ^CHOI: I didn't think it'd be important to mention.
^PARANOIA: We need to push him further. Make him squirm.
^ERGOMANIA: Does it matter? We've got the information we need...

s: ^Come on, I know there's more to it. I'm sure Jennings would love to know you made it harder for the phone to be repaired...
^Fine, whatever. None of my business anyway.

c-0: ^CHOI: Eleni and I started working at Metcom around the same time. We immediately got along.
^CHOI: She was good. Really good at her job. So good that her husband left her.
^ERGOMANIA: She was married to the work, huh? Sounds familiar.

^CHOI: After the divorce, she got really into... what do you call it? New Age stuff? It was surprising considering how methodologically scientific she is. She was always going on about transmissions and the evil eye. It got worse when we were transferred here a few months ago.

^CHOI: She was still good at her job, though. And after years of service she started getting recognition and awards from the bigger Research teams... they wanted to move her to the big shot team at HQ.
^CHOI: I couldn't stand it. Her moving on up and me being stuck with Jennings. You know they sent him here because they couldn't fire him? Being here is worse than being fired.
^CHOI: I started fabricating things. Making puzzles for her to solve, encouraging the conspiracy stuff. I'd make a different set of data for her to look at, I researched numerology just for that.
^CHOI: She got deeper and deeper into it, way further than I thought she would.
^CHOI: I thought I'd do it just enough for HQ Research to decide against moving her... but the damage was done. I didn't need to do anything anymore, the spiral sustained itself, you know.
^CHOI: And then a few days ago she crossed some threshold, past the event horizon. And here we are now.
^CHOI: When you brought her up... I panicked. I didn't think you'd notice.
^CHOI: It's probably my fault she's gone.
^CHOI: That's... that's why I need you to check on her.

s: ^Ah... shit. I'm sorry for pushing you.

c-0: ^CHOI: It's... it's okay. I shouldn't have lied.
c-1: ^CHOI: I know. I'm sorry. I'm so sorry.

g-3: ^CHOI: Is... is there anything else you need?

s: ^Hey. Just fixed the phone. Don't know about the lights, though.

g-0: ^CHOI: The lights... I'm sure they'll send someone else to do it, somehow.

jennings_Intro: ^ERGOMANIA: Wow, that's some advanced single-finger typing. This guy is hard at work.

s: ^Uh... I'll leave you alone for now. (Leave)

g-0: ^PARANOIA: He's ignoring us. He knows we're not *actually* up to the task.
^ERGOMANIA: No way. He's just really, really focusing on work. Which at the moment seems to be entirely about typing words with two out of the ten fingers he has. I wouldn't want this guy as my boss.

s: ^Fine. I'll just talk to your colleague.

c-3: ^JENNINGS: Quit staring at me like that!
^JENNINGS: Disrupting my focus like that. Unbelievable.
^JENNINGS: That guy. Talk to him. Alright?

choi_IntroFirst: ^JENNINGS: Don't ya have a phone to check on?

jennings_InProgress: ^JENNINGS: What now? Keep it short. I'm very busy.

s: ^I've checked on the phone. Someone tampered with it.
^I found an antique phone in the basement.

b: ^ Choi told me you could tell me about it.
^ Would you know anything about it?

s: ^(Point at messy desk) Do you know whose desk that is?

jennings_metphoneInspected: ^JENNINGS: Ah, must be Choi, that useless prick. Always making things hard for me.
^JENNINGS: I should report him and have him fired once and for all... he's got two strikes against him already...
^JENNINGS: But then the work would slow down and... I lose the leverage I have over him... Ha! No, I can't do that yet.
^ERGOMANIA: This man is a parasite. He's got no respect for any of the work that's being done around here.

s: ^Right. You wouldn't know anything about getting the missing part for it?

g-0: ^JENNINGS: Absolutely not. That's Choi work, not Jennings work.
^JENNINGS: He sourced the generator. That's been... helpful, although we did lose six hours of work because of how slow he was in bringing that generator here.
^JENNINGS: What else? I need to get back to this.
^JENNINGS: A MTEC Class B unit then, most likely! Those are beautiful machines.
^JENNINGS: MTEC stands for Metropoliton Telephone Exchange Company. If you ever wondered where the name "Metcom" came from...

^JENNINGS: The yanks would never admit to it, but the first sound-powered telephones were actually invented here, in this City, a good sixty years before they ever even thought of one. A miracle of good old Australian engineering!
^ERGOMANIA: He sounds like a different person now that we're talking about something he likes. I'd encourage him to continue, there's probably some valuable information in here somewhere.
g-1: ^JENNINGS: I'm glad a young girl like you is interested in such machinery. Let me explain. Sound-powered telephones like the one you found are entirely independent from any telephone exchange network. You don't need any external power. As long as the circuit is live, all you need is to just speak into the receiver.
^JENNINGS: Even in the event of a loss of power... it'd still be functional. That's the real genius about it.
g-2: ^JENNINGS: It's not "basically a hotline", it is *the* Hotline!
^JENNINGS: I do wonder where it leads. If it's in the basement, I'd surmise it connects directly to Central. Headquarter higher-ups.

^JENNINGS: Maybe you don't even need to repair that modern proprietary MetPhone horseshit. Just use the Class B! Way better--and more reliable--technology! Wish we'd still make those. How far has this company fallen...

s: ^Sounds cool. The only problem is it's locked in a cabinet.
^I think I'd rather stick with the mordern proprietary MetPhone horseshit.

c-4: ^JENNINGS: Ah. Well, this *is* the Eastern Exchange Building, the Dusty And Doomed Exchange Building where they've transfered a whole bunch of archival documents from all over to prepare for the handover into privatisation.
^JENNINGS: Anyway, bet you'd find something useful in the Archives level.
c-5: ^JENNINGS: As expected from a clueless young girl...
^JENNINGS: Well, suit yourself. But if you change your mind, there should be manuals and documentation lying around in the Archives level.

g-3: ^JENNINGS: I wish I could go see with my own eyes, unfortunately I am hard at work... Ah...
^JENNINGS: Anyway. Did you find anything else that's interesting?

jennings_petradeskInspected: ^JENNINGS: Whose desk? Ah! That's Petrakis' desk. Where did she go? There's much work to do.

g-0: ^JENNINGS: Yes! The third and final member of my team... we're awfully reduced compared to the glory days of telecom, I used to lead a team of dozens! Dozens!
^JENNINGS: So many good people laid off in preparation for this... preposterous privatisation scheme. All replaced by cheap contractors like yourself.

s: ^Okay. I'd like to know more about Petrakis, though.

g-1: ^JENNINGS: Petrakis is my assistant researcher! More competent than Choi, for sure, although these days she's been quite flaky.
^JENNINGS: Well, maybe it's good that she's gone. Choi and her were probably scheming against me behind my back. Thick as thieves, those two.

b: ^ PARANOIA: Oh. This must be what Choi is lying about. It's gonna feel good to let him know... that we know.

s: ^Wait, Choi pretended he didn't know her.
^Looks like I'll have to ask Choi about her.

c-3: ^JENNINGS: Typical. He always was envious of her and he'd do anything for a promotion.

s: ^Looks like I'll have to ask Choi about her.

g-2: ^JENNINGS: Of course! Of course. Now whether he'll be candid about her... but I digress.
^JENNINGS: More questions? I really need to get back to my work.

g-0: ^JENNINGS: Now to see how long they take to restore power...

oldphone_Inspect: ^It's a very old phone. Says "1887 - MTEC" on it.
petradesk_Inspect: ^This desk is weird. Why is it so messy? Why are there so many documents on it?

s: ^Dr Petrakis? I need to talk to you.

c-0: ^PETRAKIS: Who are you? What do you want?

c-3: ^PETRAKIS: Well, you have no idea. You have no idea what they do.

g-1: ^PETRAKIS: Why is Metcom sending lackeys to my address anyway? I know I didn't put my two weeks in, but since when do they care?

s: ^I was actually sent to fix the Metphone in the Eastern Exchange Building...
^That's not what I'm here for, I'm here about the Metphone you broke.

g-2: ^PETRAKIS: Of course, I broke it. It was an imperative I couldn't ignore. It was in the numbers, in the data.
^PETRAKIS: The chirping wires and the ultra-low frequency transmissions... the nurturing of coccoons in the fabric of the city... It's unacceptable.
^PETRAKIS: Out of curiosity, did Choi rat me out? Always knew he'd fuck me over someday.
g-3: ^PETRAKIS: You seem smart enough. I'd be happy to tell you all about what Metcom's been doing under our feet for years.

petrakis_MetphoneQuestions: ^PETRAKIS: Go on, ask me about that phone.

s: ^Okay. I think I know what's going on here.
^What did you do with the power core?
^Why did you run away from the Research team?
^Actually, I've got other things to do right now. (Leave)

c-4: ^PETRAKIS: Suit yourself. I'll be here whenever you decide to face the truth.

break: ^PETRAKIS: Think about it. What do you think they were doing with that thing?
^PETRAKIS: Spying on us, demanding regular contact... but not just that! There's something strange with the receiver. The voices...

^PETRAKIS: The other two, Choi, Jennings. They never went down to do the handshake. They always made me do it, because they reckoned the work was lesser, even though I'm more competent than both of them combined.
^PETRAKIS: It was always me. At first it was normal, just like every other handshake I've ever done in my twenty years here.
^PETRAKIS: I can't unhear them. There is something evil and haunted in the wires.

s: ^Haha. The voices. Yeah. Isn't it just interference?

g-0: ^PETRAKIS: The Metphone is on a closed circuit. There can't be interference.
^PETRAKIS: I had to break it. Sever the line between their world and ours. Maybe if you heard it you would understand better...

powercore: ^PETRAKIS: Have you seen inside the phone?

c-0: ^PETRAKIS: Then you already know it's pointless to try and ram a power core in the guts of that thing.
c-1: ^PETRAKIS: Well, if you did, you'd know it's pointless to try and ram a power core in the guts of that thing.

quitting: ^PETRAKIS: I used to love the job, you know? I really did. I thought it was the most important thing, and then it took everything from me...
^PETRAKIS: Twenty years of service and for what!

petrakis_InProgress: ^PARANOIA: She's definitely onto something. There's something seriously wrong with Metcom.
^ERGOMANIA: She's just burnt out and needs something that justifies her quitting.

s: ^You're onto something. I always thought something was weird about Metcom.
^Of course I do. I'm doing my own investigation into a Metcom-related mystery myself.

g-0: ^PETRAKIS: You're the first person to actually take me seriously about this.
g-1: ^PETRAKIS: Marisol! You can call me Eleni.

s: ^I do still need to fix that phone, or I won't be able to infiltrate Metcom anymore.
^Do you know anything about this egg?

c-2: ^PETRAKIS: Yes. About that, I think we can turn fixing the Metphone to our advantage.
^PETRAKIS: I need an organic sample. A transluscent egg-like sac that grows in human bodies...
^PETRAKIS: I found such an organism in a Hardware Store nearby. The sample I retrieved from there unfortunately did not survive some of my... experiments.
^PETRAKIS: Would you be able to fetch me one?

rationalist: ^PETRAKIS: I want nothing to do with Metcom anymore...

s: ^Wait! I still need to fix the Metphone.
^Wait! I need to know what's going on with this egg.

c-0: ^PETRAKIS: Good luck doing it without my help.

rationalist: ^PETRAKIS: Were you spying on my research as well?
^PETRAKIS: Trying to take over my work and get credit for it?
^PETRAKIS: I can't help you with that. Sorry.
^ERGOMANIA: Yes she can. She's smarter than everyone else and knows what she's doing. Just needs convincing...

s: ^I'm not trying to get any credit for anything. I just want to fix this phone so I don't get fired. You're clearly smarter and better than me and I just need help.

conspiracist: ^PETRAKIS: The egg! There it is. Thank you.
hint: ^PETRAKIS: Eggs like that one are somehow compatible with the Metphone.
^PETRAKIS: Same frequency, same voltage. You could think of it as a miracle of life, but the truth is much simpler: Metcom has been "growing" these inside human hosts.
^PETRAKIS: This is a great specimen. I think it'll survive the symbiotic relationship with...
^PETRAKIS: My bug! Get this, Marisol. We're *actually* bugging Metcom HQ!
^PETRAKIS: Here you go. Attach it to the egg once it's connected to the phone's guts.
^PETRAKIS: There you go. There's your hint.
^PETRAKIS: Now go fix that phone, bootlicker.

s: ^(Pretending not to hear her) Hello? Hellooooo?

c-1: ^SAM: Yeah, yeah. Funny. I could hang up on you and you won't get work for the day. See how you like that.

s: ^I'm sorry. I'm here. How are you?
^I'd just keep calling you. How's it goin' Sam?

g-0: ^SAM: Wait, not the usual. Coffee machine closest to *my* desk is broken. So now *I* have to walk all the way up to Logistics to get a coffee now. Dez, I'm gonna do it this time. I'm gonna quit this crappy job.
^SAM: Anyway, I've got a fun one for you today.

c-2: ^SAM: Nah. None of the jobs they give us are *fun*. Especially not this one.

g-1: ^SAM: I got this report about the... Eastern Exchange Building.
^SAM: I thought they had decommissioned that building but somehow it's still operating. Not like they would tell me anything actually important, but you know.
^SAM: Says "urgent" on it but I'll be honest, they put that on almost every folder they send down here.

s: ^So what's the situation with the exchange building?

g-3: ^SAM: The report says that the building's "gone dark". The Research team in there failed a critical handshake and someone needs to check in on them and restore communications with HQ.
g-4: ^SAM: Correct. Lucky you! You get to meet with freaks from Research!
^SAM: Of course it's bloody Research. They screw up their duties and we're the ones who have to clean up after them.

s: ^Sam, I'm the one who's doing the clean up. You're just sitting at a desk.
^Right. How will I... restore communications with HQ?

c-8: ^SAM: I thought we were a team?

s: ^We are. How will I restore communications with HQ?

g-5: ^SAM: There's going to be a phone there, kinda like this one. That's the Universal Hotline. You'll have to figure out what's wrong with it and reconnect it.

s: ^That sounds like it's gonna be complicated.

c-10: ^SAM: It's Metcom we're talking about. Nothing's ever easy here, Dez, and you know that.
c-11: ^SAM: Yup. Welcome to working at Metcom. Although you don't need me to tell you that.

g-6: ^SAM: Do check that the Research team is alive and haven't all been, I don't know, eaten by giant bugs or whatever.

s: ^Can you tell me what I need to do again?

c-12: ^SAM: Go to the Eastern Exchange Building.
^SAM: Check that the Research team is still alive.
^SAM: Diagnose the problem with the Hotline, and find a way to fix it.
^SAM: Restore communications with HQ, and ta-da! You're done.
^SAM: Oh and call me when you're done. Obviously.
